canonical_explanation.text: Disease is a condition that impairs normal body functions. Pathogens (disease-causing organisms) include bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and parasitic worms. Diseases are classified as infectious (communicable) and non-infectious (non-communicable). Transmission occurs through direct contact, air, water, food, and vectors. Immunity is the body's ability to resist disease. Innate immunity (present from birth) includes physical barriers (skin, mucus) and cellular defenses (WBCs, inflammation). Acquired immunity develops after exposure and involves antibodies produced by B-lymphocytes in response to antigens. Active immunity results from infection or vaccination; passive immunity involves receiving antibodies from another source. Vaccines contain weakened or killed pathogens that stimulate immune response without causing disease.
rules: Pathogens include bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and parasitic worms
Infectious diseases can spread; non-infectious diseases cannot
Transmission modes: direct contact, airborne, waterborne, foodborne, vector-borne
Innate immunity is non-specific and present from birth
Acquired immunity is specific and develops after exposure to pathogens
Active immunity: body produces its own antibodies (infection or vaccination)
Passive immunity: antibodies received from external source (mother to baby)
Antigens are foreign substances that trigger immune response
Antibodies are proteins produced by B-cells that bind to specific antigens
Vaccines stimulate immune response without causing disease

questions.question_text: Disease-causing microorganisms are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Disease-causing microorganisms are called pathogens, which is the correct answer. Pathogens include bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and parasitic worms that can cause infectious diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. Antibodies are proteins produced by the immune system to fight pathogens. Antigens are molecules that trigger an immune response. Vaccines are weakened or killed pathogens that stimulate immunity without causing disease. Pathogens are the disease-causing microorganisms, not antibodies, antigens, or vaccines.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a pathogen?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Red blood cell. Red blood cells are not pathogens, which are disease-causing organisms. Pathogens include bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa, but red blood cells are normal components of the human body that do not cause disease.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options (A. Bacteria, B. Virus, D. Fungus) are all examples of pathogens, which are disease-causing organisms. Bacteria, viruses, and fungi can all infect the human body and cause various diseases. Therefore, they are considered pathogens, unlike red blood cells which are normal parts of the human body.

questions.question_text: Diseases that can spread from one person to another are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Diseases that can spread from one person to another are called communicable diseases. This is because they can be transmitted or passed on from an infected person to a healthy person, usually through direct contact, air, water, food, or vectors like mosquitoes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because: Non-communicable diseases cannot be spread from person to person, deficiency diseases are caused by a lack of certain nutrients, and genetic diseases are passed on through inheritance, not transmission. Therefore, the correct answer is that diseases that can spread from one person to another are called communicable diseases.

questions.question_text: Diabetes is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Diabetes is an example of a non-communicable disease, which means it is not transmitted from person to person. Diabetes is a chronic condition where the body cannot properly regulate blood sugar levels, and this is not caused by an infectious pathogen like a virus or bacteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diabetes is not a communicable or infectious disease that can spread from one person to another. It is a non-communicable disease, which means it is a chronic condition that develops within an individual and is not transmitted through contact with other people, air, water, or food. Diabetes is also not caused by a viral or bacterial infection, so it is not a viral or bacterial disease either.

questions.question_text: Airborne diseases spread through:

options.text: Droplets in air when coughing or sneezing

questions.explanation_correct: Airborne diseases like the flu, common cold, and COVID-19 spread through tiny droplets in the air when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. These droplets can be inhaled by others nearby, transmitting the disease.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Airborne diseases do not spread through contaminated water, mosquito bites, or direct contact alone. While these are common ways for other types of diseases to spread, airborne diseases require respiratory droplets to travel through the air and be inhaled by others.

questions.question_text: Malaria is spread by:
questions.explanation_correct: Malaria is spread by the female Anopheles mosquito. This mosquito species carries the malaria parasite and transmits it to humans through its bite.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria is not spread through contaminated water, direct contact, or air droplets. The malaria parasite is carried and transmitted by the female Anopheles mosquito, which bites and infects humans with the disease.

questions.question_text: Cholera is transmitted through:
questions.explanation_correct: Cholera is a disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, which is typically transmitted through contaminated water or food. The bacteria can enter the body when a person drinks water or eats food that is polluted with the disease-causing microbes, leading to the development of cholera.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cholera is not transmitted through the air, mosquito bites, or direct skin contact. The disease is spread primarily through the ingestion of contaminated water or food, as the bacteria that cause cholera can be present in these sources and enter the body when a person consumes them.

questions.question_text: Animals or insects that transmit diseases are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Vectors are living organisms, such as animals or insects, that can transmit diseases from one person or organism to another. This is the correct answer because pathogens, antibodies, and vaccines are not the organisms that spread diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Vectors. Vectors are living organisms like mosquitoes, ticks, or flies that can carry and spread diseases from one person or animal to another. Pathogens are the disease-causing organisms themselves, antibodies are proteins produced by the immune system, and vaccines are substances that provide immunity against a disease, but they are not the organisms that transmit the disease.

questions.question_text: Immunity that is present from birth is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Innate immunity is the immunity that we are born with. It is the body's natural defenses against disease, including physical barriers like the skin and mucus, and cellular defenses like white blood cells. This type of immunity is present from birth and does not need to be developed after exposure to a pathogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acquired immunity is the immunity that develops after exposure to a pathogen or through vaccination. Passive immunity involves receiving antibodies from another source, such as a mother's breast milk. Artificial immunity refers to immunity created through medical intervention, such as vaccines. Innate immunity is the immunity present from birth, which is the correct answer to this question.

questions.question_text: The first line of defense in the body includes:
questions.explanation_correct: The skin and mucous membranes act as the first line of defense against pathogens entering the body. They provide a physical barrier that prevents harmful microorganisms from getting inside and causing disease.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibodies, T-cells, and vaccines do not directly act as the first line of defense in the body. Antibodies are produced by the immune system to target specific pathogens, T-cells help coordinate the immune response, and vaccines stimulate the body to produce antibodies, but these are all part of the acquired immune system which acts after the initial defense by the skin and mucous membranes.

questions.question_text: Acquired immunity develops:

options.text: After exposure to pathogens or vaccination

questions.explanation_correct: Acquired immunity develops after exposure to pathogens or vaccination, which stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies that can recognize and fight off those pathogens in the future.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acquired immunity does not develop before birth, as the immune system takes time to mature and learn to recognize pathogens. It also develops in both children and adults, not just one age group, as the body continues to build up its immune defenses throughout life.

questions.question_text: Active immunity is when:

options.text: Antibodies are received from another source
The body produces its own antibodies

questions.explanation_correct: Active immunity is when the body produces its own antibodies in response to an infection or vaccination. This allows the body to recognize and fight off the disease-causing pathogen in the future.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active immunity is not about receiving antibodies from another source (that's passive immunity). It's also not about inheriting immunity (that's innate immunity). Active immunity involves the body actively producing its own antibodies to fight off pathogens, either from an infection or a vaccine.

questions.question_text: A baby receives antibodies from its mother through breast milk. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: The baby receives antibodies from the mother through breast milk, which is an example of natural passive immunity. This means the baby gets antibodies directly from another source (the mother) without having to produce them on its own.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because natural active immunity is when the body develops its own antibodies after being exposed to a pathogen, not from receiving antibodies from another source. Option C is incorrect because artificial active immunity refers to vaccines that stimulate the body to produce its own antibodies, not receiving antibodies from another source. Option D is incorrect because artificial passive immunity refers to receiving antibodies from an external source like an injection, not from breast milk.

questions.question_text: Foreign substances that trigger an immune response are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Antigens are foreign substances that trigger an immune response from the body's defense systems. When your body detects an antigen, it produces antibodies to neutralize or destroy it, which is a key part of the immune response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibodies are proteins produced by the body's B-lymphocytes in response to antigens, not the antigens themselves. Pathogens are disease-causing organisms like bacteria and viruses, not the triggers for the immune response. Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell that participate in the immune system, but they are not the substances that trigger the response.

questions.question_text: Proteins produced by the immune system to fight antigens are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Antibodies are proteins produced by the immune system to specifically recognize and neutralize foreign substances called antigens, which can be from pathogens or other sources. This is the main role of antibodies in the body's immune response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The proteins produced by the immune system to fight antigens are called antibodies, not enzymes, hormones, or pathogens. Enzymes are biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions, hormones are chemical messengers that regulate body processes, and pathogens are the disease-causing organisms themselves, not the proteins that fight them.

questions.question_text: Antibodies are produced by:
questions.explanation_correct: Antibodies are produced by B-lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. B-lymphocytes recognize foreign substances called antigens and respond by producing antibodies to neutralize or destroy them, providing immunity against disease.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red blood cells, platelets, and neurons do not produce antibodies. Antibodies are specialized proteins made by B-lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. B-lymphocytes are the only cells in the body that can produce antibodies, which are a crucial part of the body's acquired immune response.

questions.question_text: T-cells are involved in:

options.text: Cell-mediated immunity, attacking infected cells directly

questions.explanation_correct: T-cells are involved in cell-mediated immunity, which means they attack infected cells directly rather than producing antibodies. This helps the body eliminate pathogens that have already infected cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T-cells are not involved in producing antibodies, which is the job of B-cells. They also do not play a role in blood clotting or carrying oxygen, which are functions of other blood cells. The correct answer is that T-cells are responsible for cell-mediated immunity by directly attacking infected cells in the body.

questions.question_text: Vaccines contain:
questions.explanation_correct: Vaccines contain weakened or killed pathogens because this helps the body's immune system recognize and fight off the disease, without actually causing the illness. This trains the body to mount an immune response, providing protection against the full-strength pathogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccines do not contain strong live pathogens, as this would cause the disease the vaccine is trying to prevent. They also do not contain antibiotics or hormones - those are used for different medical purposes. Vaccines specifically have weakened or killed pathogens, which stimulate the immune system to build antibodies and provide protection without making the person sick.

questions.question_text: Vaccination provides which type of immunity?
questions.explanation_correct: Vaccination provides artificial active immunity. Vaccines contain weakened or killed pathogens that stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies, without causing the actual disease. This active immune response helps the body fight off future infections, even if exposed to the real pathogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccination does not provide natural passive immunity, which involves receiving antibodies from another source. Vaccination also does not provide natural active immunity, which develops from an actual infection. Vaccination also does not provide innate immunity, which is the body's initial, non-specific defenses against pathogens.

questions.question_text: Herd immunity occurs when:

options.text: A large percentage of population is immune, protecting others

questions.explanation_correct: Herd immunity occurs when a large percentage of the population is immune to a disease, either through vaccination or previous exposure. This protects even those who are not immune, as the virus or bacteria has fewer opportunities to spread and infect people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because herd immunity does not require everyone to be vaccinated, just a large enough percentage of the population. Option C is incorrect because herd immunity refers to the immunity of the human population, not animals. Option D is incorrect because antibiotics treat bacterial infections, not provide immunity to diseases.

questions.question_text: Tuberculosis is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Tuberculosis is caused by a type of bacteria called Mycobacterium tuberculosis, so the correct answer is B) Bacteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tuberculosis is not caused by a virus, fungus, or protozoa. It is a bacterial disease, so the correct answer is B) Bacteria. Viruses, fungi, and protozoa are other types of pathogens that can cause different diseases, but they do not cause tuberculosis.

questions.question_text: AIDS is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus). AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by the HIV virus, which attacks the body's immune system and weakens its ability to fight infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AIDS is not caused by bacteria, fungi, or protozoa. It is caused by the HIV virus, which is a type of virus that specifically targets and weakens the human immune system over time. This allows other infections and diseases to take hold more easily in the body.

questions.question_text: Typhoid is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Typhoid fever is caused by the Salmonella bacteria, which is the correct answer. This infectious disease is transmitted through contaminated food and water, and can lead to fever, headache, and gastrointestinal issues if left untreated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typhoid is not caused by a virus, Plasmodium (which causes malaria), or a fungus. The correct answer is that typhoid is caused by the Salmonella bacteria, which can infect the digestive system and spread through poor hygiene and contaminated sources.

questions.question_text: Dengue is spread by:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Aedes mosquito. Dengue is a viral disease that is spread by the Aedes mosquito, which is the primary vector for the dengue virus. The Aedes mosquito, specifically the Aedes aegypti species, is known to transmit the dengue virus when it bites an infected person and then feeds on another person.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Anopheles mosquito is the vector for malaria, not dengue. C) Houseflies can transmit some diseases, but they are not the vector for dengue. D) Contaminated water can lead to various waterborne diseases, but dengue is not spread through water. The Aedes mosquito is the correct vector for the transmission of the dengue virus.

questions.question_text: Common cold is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: The common cold is caused by viruses, specifically rhinoviruses. Viruses are small infectious agents that can only replicate inside living cells, unlike bacteria which can live independently. This makes viruses the correct cause of the common cold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common cold is not caused by bacteria, fungi, or protozoa. These are other types of pathogens that can cause different diseases, but the common cold is specifically caused by viruses, particularly rhinoviruses. Viruses are much smaller than bacteria and have a different method of infecting and replicating inside the host's cells.

questions.question_text: Why is a person usually immune to chickenpox after recovering from it once?

options.text: Memory cells are formed that respond quickly to reinfection

questions.explanation_correct: When a person recovers from chickenpox, their body creates memory cells that can quickly recognize and respond to the chickenpox virus if it tries to infect the person again. This means the person becomes immune to getting chickenpox a second time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the virus is not permanently destroyed - it remains in the body even after recovery. Option C is incorrect because the skin does not become resistant; it is the immune system that becomes stronger. Option D is incorrect because antibiotics do not kill viruses like the one that causes chickenpox.

questions.question_text: Why do we need booster doses of some vaccines?

options.text: The first dose does not work
Immunity decreases over time and needs reinforcement

questions.explanation_correct: Immunity from vaccines decreases over time, so booster doses are needed to reinforce the immune system and maintain protection against the disease. The first dose stimulates the initial immune response, but this can fade after some time, so additional doses are required to keep the immunity strong.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first dose of a vaccine does work, but the immunity it provides can weaken over time. Booster doses are not to cure the disease or increase the dosage, but to keep the immune system primed and ready to fight the disease if exposed again. Booster shots help the body maintain the necessary antibodies to provide long-term protection.

questions.question_text: Autoimmune diseases occur when:

options.text: The immune system is too weak
The immune system attacks the body's own cells
There are no white blood cells

questions.explanation_correct: Autoimmune diseases occur when the immune system attacks the body's own healthy cells and tissues, instead of just targeting foreign pathogens. This results in the immune system damaging the body's own cells and organs, causing various autoimmune disorders.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Autoimmune diseases do not occur because the immune system is too weak. In fact, they happen when the immune system is overactive and starts attacking the body's own cells. The correct answer is that autoimmune diseases occur when the immune system mistakenly targets the body's own healthy cells, not because of a lack of white blood cells or pathogens becoming too strong.

questions.question_text: Viruses are considered non-living outside a host because they:

options.text: Cannot reproduce without a host cell

questions.explanation_correct: Viruses are considered non-living outside a host cell because they cannot reproduce on their own. They need to infect a living host cell and hijack its machinery to make copies of themselves, so option B is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Viruses are not considered non-living because they lack the ability to move (option A) or because they are too small in size (option D). While viruses do not have their own DNA (option C), this is not the reason they are considered non-living outside a host cell. The key reason is that they cannot reproduce without a host cell, which is why option B is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Antibiotic resistance occurs because:

options.text: Bacteria evolve and become resistant to antibiotics

questions.explanation_correct: Bacteria evolve and become resistant to antibiotics because of the process of natural selection. When some bacteria are exposed to antibiotics, the ones with random genetic mutations that make them resistant to the antibiotics survive, reproduce, and pass on their resistant traits to future generations. This allows the resistant bacteria to thrive and spread, while the non-resistant ones are killed off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotics are not too strong - in fact, the strength of antibiotics has allowed them to effectively kill bacteria in the past. Antibiotic resistance also does not occur because the immune system becomes weak. The correct reason is that bacteria evolve and adapt to become resistant to the antibiotics used against them. Viruses can also mutate, but that is not the cause of antibiotic resistance, which is a bacterial phenomenon.

questions.question_text: All microorganisms cause diseases.
questions.explanation_correct: Not all microorganisms cause diseases. Many microbes are harmless or even beneficial to the human body. Only certain types of microbes, called pathogens, can cause diseases by infecting and harming the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not true that all microorganisms cause diseases. Many microbes are actually helpful or neutral to our health. Only a small subset of microbes, known as pathogens, have the ability to infect the body and cause diseases. The majority of microbes that live in and around us do not have any harmful effects.

questions.question_text: Mosquitoes are vectors for malaria and dengue.
questions.explanation_correct: Mosquitoes are known to be vectors (carriers) for certain infectious diseases, including malaria and dengue fever. They can transmit these diseases by biting infected people and then biting healthy individuals, allowing the pathogens to spread.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think mosquitoes are not involved in the transmission of diseases like malaria and dengue. However, mosquitoes play a crucial role as vectors for these illnesses. They pick up the disease-causing parasites or viruses when they bite an infected person, and then spread the pathogens to healthy individuals during their subsequent bites.

questions.question_text: Innate immunity is specific to particular pathogens.
questions.explanation_correct: Innate immunity is not specific to particular pathogens. It provides a general defense against a wide range of disease-causing organisms. Innate immunity includes physical barriers like the skin and mucus, as well as cellular defenses like white blood cells, which can attack many different types of pathogens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Innate immunity is a general, non-specific defense system that is present from birth. It does not target or respond to particular pathogens. This is different from acquired immunity, which develops after exposure to a specific pathogen and involves producing antibodies to fight that particular disease-causing organism.

questions.question_text: Acquired immunity develops after exposure to pathogens.
questions.explanation_correct: Acquired immunity develops after exposure to pathogens. This means that when your body encounters a disease-causing organism for the first time, it learns to recognize it and produces special cells called antibodies to fight it off. This acquired immune response helps protect you against that disease in the future.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acquired immunity is different from innate immunity, which is the body's natural defense against diseases from birth. Acquired immunity is the immunity that develops after you've been exposed to a pathogen and your body has learned to recognize and fight it. This is why the statement 'Acquired immunity develops after exposure to pathogens' is true.

questions.question_text: Antibodies are produced by T-lymphocytes.
questions.explanation_correct: Antibodies are produced by B-lymphocytes, not T-lymphocytes. T-lymphocytes have a different role in the immune system, which is to directly attack and destroy infected cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T-lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell that play an important role in the immune system, but they do not produce antibodies. Antibodies are produced by a different type of white blood cell called B-lymphocytes. The B-lymphocytes make antibodies that recognize and bind to specific pathogens, helping to eliminate them from the body.

questions.question_text: Vaccines can cause the disease they are meant to prevent.
questions.explanation_correct: Vaccines do not cause the disease they are meant to prevent. Vaccines contain weakened or killed pathogens that stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies, without actually causing the disease. This allows the body to build immunity and be prepared to fight the disease if exposed in the future.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that vaccines can cause the disease they are meant to prevent. However, this is false. Vaccines contain only small amounts of weakened or inactivated forms of the pathogen, which are not enough to cause the actual disease. Instead, they trigger the immune system to produce antibodies, so the body is prepared to fight off the disease if exposed in the future.

questions.question_text: Vaccination provides artificial active immunity.
questions.explanation_correct: Vaccination provides artificial active immunity because it introduces weakened or killed pathogens into the body, which stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies without causing the actual disease. This allows the body to be prepared to fight off the real infection later on.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccination is not a form of passive immunity, which involves receiving antibodies from another source. Instead, vaccines contain weakened or killed pathogens that trigger the body's own immune response, leading to active immunity against that disease. This is different from passive immunity, which does not require the body to produce its own antibodies.

questions.question_text: Antibiotics are effective against viral infections.
questions.explanation_correct: Antibiotics are not effective against viral infections because they work by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria, not viruses. Viruses are different from bacteria and require different treatments like antiviral medications.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because antibiotics target bacteria, not viruses. Viruses have a different structure and life cycle compared to bacteria, so antibiotics are not able to kill or stop the spread of viral infections. Instead, antiviral medications are used to treat viral diseases.

questions.question_text: Passive immunity lasts longer than active immunity.
questions.explanation_correct: Passive immunity lasts for a shorter duration than active immunity. Passive immunity involves receiving antibodies from another source, such as a mother's milk or an injection. This provides immediate protection, but the antibodies gradually get used up or eliminated from the body over time. In contrast, active immunity develops after exposure to a pathogen or vaccine, and the body continues to produce antibodies, providing long-lasting protection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is actually incorrect that passive immunity lasts longer than active immunity. Passive immunity provides short-term protection, as the antibodies received from an external source are eventually used up or eliminated from the body. Active immunity, on the other hand, involves the body's own immune system producing antibodies in response to a pathogen or vaccine, and this provides long-lasting protection against the disease.

questions.question_text: Memory cells help the immune system respond faster to repeated infections.
questions.explanation_correct: Memory cells help the immune system respond faster to repeated infections because they store information about past infections. When the same pathogen is encountered again, the memory cells can quickly activate an appropriate immune response to fight the infection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because memory cells do not help the immune system respond faster to repeated infections. Memory cells are a type of lymphocyte that stores information about past infections. When the same pathogen is encountered again, the memory cells can quickly activate an appropriate immune response to fight the infection, making the immune system more effective at fighting the disease.

questions.question_text: Disease-causing organisms are called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Disease-causing organisms are called pathogens because they are the agents that can infect and make our bodies sick. Pathogens include bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, and parasitic worms that can disrupt normal body functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The word 'pathogens' refers to disease-causing organisms, which is the exact answer expected in this question. Pathogens are the microscopic living things that can invade our bodies and make us ill. Other terms like 'germs' or 'microbes' are not the specific word asked for in this fill-in-the-blank question.

questions.question_text: Animals that transmit diseases from one host to another are called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Vectors are organisms that transmit diseases from one host to another. They pick up pathogens from an infected host and spread them to a new, uninfected host. Common vectors include mosquitoes, ticks, and fleas that carry viruses, bacteria, or parasites and pass them on as they bite and feed on different hosts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'vectors'. Vectors are living organisms that can transmit diseases from one host to another. They pick up pathogens from an infected host and pass them on to a new, uninfected host. This is different from direct transmission between hosts or transmission through non-living agents like water or air. The key characteristic of a vector is its ability to physically carry and spread the disease-causing organism.

questions.question_text: Immunity present from birth is called _____ immunity.
questions.explanation_correct: Immunity present from birth is called innate immunity. This is because innate immunity is the body's natural defense system that is already in place since birth, without needing previous exposure to a disease. Innate immunity includes physical barriers like the skin and mucus, as well as cellular defenses like white blood cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'innate' immunity. Innate immunity refers to the body's natural defenses that are present from birth, as opposed to 'acquired' immunity which develops after exposure to a disease or vaccine. Innate immunity does not require any prior experience with a disease to function, and includes physical barriers like the skin and mucus as well as cellular defenses like white blood cells.

questions.question_text: When the body produces its own antibodies, it is called _____ immunity.
questions.explanation_correct: When the body produces its own antibodies in response to a pathogen or vaccine, it is called active immunity. This is because the body's immune system is actively fighting the infection or threat, and generating its own antibodies to protect against future infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'active' immunity. Passive immunity involves receiving antibodies from another source, such as a mother's breastmilk or a shot of antibodies. In active immunity, the body produces its own antibodies to fight off a disease or infection, either through exposure to the pathogen or through vaccination.

questions.question_text: Foreign substances that trigger an immune response are called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Foreign substances that trigger an immune response are called antigens. Antigens are molecules, such as proteins or carbohydrates, that are recognized by the body's immune system as 'foreign' and stimulate the production of antibodies to fight them off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is antigens. The term 'antigens' refers to foreign substances that trigger an immune response in the body. Antigens can be proteins, carbohydrates, or other molecules that are recognized as 'non-self' by the immune system, which then produces antibodies to neutralize or eliminate them.

questions.question_text: Proteins produced by B-cells to fight pathogens are called _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The proteins produced by B-cells to fight pathogens are called antibodies. Antibodies are specialized proteins that can recognize and bind to specific parts of pathogens, called antigens, to neutralize or destroy them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'antibodies'. Antibodies are proteins produced by B-cells, a type of white blood cell, to recognize and fight against specific pathogens that enter the body. They do this by binding to the pathogens and marking them for destruction by other parts of the immune system.

questions.question_text: _____ contain weakened or killed pathogens to stimulate immunity.
questions.explanation_correct: Vaccines contain weakened or killed pathogens because this stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies without causing the actual disease. This prepares the body to fight off the real pathogen if it is encountered later.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccines, not other treatments, contain weakened or killed pathogens to stimulate immunity. This is because vaccines are designed to trigger an immune response and build up protection against specific diseases, unlike other medical interventions that may treat symptoms or underlying conditions.

questions.question_text: Tuberculosis is caused by _____ bacteria.
questions.explanation_correct: Tuberculosis is caused by bacteria from the genus Mycobacterium, specifically Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This is the correct answer as Mycobacterium is the specific type of bacteria that leads to the disease tuberculosis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Mycobacterium', which is the correct answer. Tuberculosis is not caused by just any type of bacteria, but by the specific Mycobacterium bacteria. Understanding the exact pathogen that causes a disease is important in identifying and treating it properly.

questions.question_text: Malaria is spread by the female _____ mosquito.
questions.explanation_correct: The female Anopheles mosquito is the vector that transmits the malaria parasite to humans. This mosquito species is the only one capable of carrying and spreading the Plasmodium parasite that causes malaria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Anopheles'. Malaria is not spread by other mosquito species like Culex or Aedes. The female Anopheles mosquito has a specific anatomy and behavior that allows it to pick up the malaria parasite from an infected person and transmit it to a healthy person through its bite.

questions.question_text: AIDS is caused by the _____ virus.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) because HIV is the virus that causes the disease called AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'HIV'. AIDS is not caused by a generic 'virus', but specifically by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). HIV is a unique virus that attacks the body's immune system, weakening it over time and leading to the development of AIDS, the advanced stage of the disease.

questions.question_text: When a large percentage of population is immune, protecting non-immune individuals, it is called _____ immunity.
questions.explanation_correct: When a large percentage of the population is immune to a disease, it prevents the spread of the disease to non-immune individuals. This is called 'herd immunity', where the entire community is protected even if some people are not directly immune themselves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer format is 'herd'. The term 'herd immunity' refers to a situation where a large portion of a population becomes immune to a disease, either through vaccination or previous exposure. This makes it difficult for the disease to spread from person to person, ultimately protecting even those who are not directly immune.

questions.question_text: _____ cells remember previous infections and help in faster immune response.
questions.explanation_correct: Memory cells are a type of lymphocyte (white blood cell) that remember past infections and pathogens the body has encountered. This allows the immune system to respond faster and more effectively if the same pathogen is encountered again in the future.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Memory' cells. Memory cells are a type of lymphocyte that 'remember' previous infections the body has faced. This allows the immune system to respond faster and more effectively if the same pathogen is encountered again. Other types of immune cells like white blood cells do not have this memory function.

questions.question_text: Arrange the lines of defense in order (first to last):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is physical barriers (skin, mucus), inflammation and phagocytosis, and antibody production. This is the sequence of the body's defense mechanisms, starting with the first line of defense (physical barriers), followed by the innate immune response (inflammation and phagocytosis), and lastly the adaptive immune response (antibody production).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be antibody production, inflammation and phagocytosis, physical barriers. This is not the correct sequence because the body's first line of defense against pathogens is the physical barriers like the skin and mucus, which prevent the entry of disease-causing organisms. The next step is the innate immune response, which involves inflammation and phagocytosis by white blood cells. Only after these initial defenses, the adaptive immune system produces specific antibodies to fight the infection.

questions.question_text: Arrange the immune response steps in order:
ordering_items: Memory cells formed for future protection
correct_answer: Memory cells formed for future protection
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of the immune response steps is: Pathogen enters body, Antigen recognized by immune cells, B-cells produce antibodies, Memory cells formed for future protection. This is the sequence of events that occurs when the body encounters a pathogen and mounts an immune response to fight it off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Memory cells formed for future protection, B-cells produce antibodies, Antigen recognized by immune cells, Pathogen enters body. This is incorrect because the immune response starts with the pathogen entering the body, which is then recognized by immune cells. B-cells then produce antibodies to neutralize the pathogen, and memory cells are formed to provide faster response in the future.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps of how a vaccine works:
ordering_items: Full immune response if exposed to actual pathogen
correct_answer: Full immune response if exposed to actual pathogen
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Vaccine containing weakened pathogen given > Immune system produces antibodies > Memory cells formed > Full immune response if exposed to actual pathogen. This is the sequence of how a vaccine works - the weakened pathogen in the vaccine stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies and form memory cells, which then provide a faster and stronger immune response when the actual pathogen is encountered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Full immune response if exposed to actual pathogen > Vaccine containing weakened pathogen given > Immune system produces antibodies > Memory cells formed. This is incorrect because the immune response comes AFTER the vaccine is administered and the immune system produces antibodies in response to the weakened pathogen in the vaccine. The memory cells are then formed, which allow for a faster and stronger response if the actual pathogen is encountered later.

questions.question_text: Arrange the malaria infection cycle in order:
ordering_items: Parasites multiply in liver and blood cells
correct_answer: Parasites multiply in liver and blood cells
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of the malaria infection cycle is: Infected mosquito bites person, Plasmodium enters bloodstream, Parasites multiply in liver and blood cells, Symptoms appear (fever, chills). This is because the malaria parasite (Plasmodium) is first transmitted from an infected mosquito to a person, and then the parasite multiplies in the liver and blood before causing the characteristic symptoms of malaria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Parasites multiply in liver and blood cells, Symptoms appear (fever, chills), Infected mosquito bites person, Plasmodium enters bloodstream. This is wrong because the infection starts when an infected mosquito bites a person, allowing the Plasmodium parasite to enter the bloodstream. The parasite then multiplies in the liver and blood cells before the symptoms of malaria appear.

questions.question_text: Arrange immunity types from shortest to longest lasting:
questions.explanation_correct: Passive immunity from antibody injection is the shortest lasting, as the injected antibodies are eventually broken down by the body. Passive immunity from mother's milk lasts longer, until the antibodies are no longer present in the milk. Active immunity from vaccination is the longest lasting, as it involves the body producing its own antibodies that can remain for years or even a lifetime.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from shortest to longest lasting immunity is: Passive immunity from antibody injection, Passive immunity from mother's milk, Active immunity from vaccination. Passive immunity involves receiving pre-made antibodies, either through injection or from a mother's milk, and these antibodies only last for a limited time. In contrast, active immunity from vaccination leads to the body producing its own antibodies that can provide long-term protection.
